definitions.definition: the process or method of building or making something, especially roads, buildings, bridges, etc.

examples.text: Construction began this year and will take approximately 18 months.
the costs of **road construction** and maintenance
Work has begun on the construction of the new airport.
the construction of a new database
Our new offices are still under construction *(= being built)*.
Ethernet cabling was installed during construction.
the **construction industry**
**construction work/workers**
a **construction company/firm**
**construction projects/costs/materials**
Construction of the new road has now been completed.
Major engineering challenges will be faced during construction.
The drainage system needs careful construction.
the heavy construction industry

definitions.definition: the people and activities involved in making buildings

examples.text: 50 000 more jobs will go from construction in the next five years.

definitions.definition: the way that something has been built or made

examples.text: The bridges are similar in construction.
ships of steel construction
It has a basic construction of brick under a tiled roof.
The earliest Greek temples were small buildings, simple in construction.
walls of solid construction
a schoolhouse of brick construction

definitions.definition: a thing that has been built or made

examples.text: The summer house was a simple wooden construction.
a massive steel construction
a two-storey brick construction
massive constructions of bamboo and paper

definitions.definition: the way in which words are used together and arranged to form a sentence, phrase, etc.

examples.text: grammatical constructions

definitions.definition: the creating of something from ideas, opinions and knowledge

examples.text: the construction of a new theory
changes in the social construction of marriage

definitions.definition: the way in which words, actions, statements, etc. are understood by somebody

examples.text: What construction do you put on this letter *(= what do you think it means)*?
ruling on the proper construction to be given to section 78 of the Act
a strict construction of the clause

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin constructio(n-), from construere ‘heap together’, from con- ‘together’ + struere ‘pile, build’.
